title: The Current Meta and ELO (or MMR) Hell
body:
A lot of people refute the existence of ELO hell.  You can call them stupid or ignorant, but fact probably stands that they've just not encountered it.  And if you have never seen or experienced something, it can be hard to believe it exists, even if others claim it does.

Regardless of whether you believe it does or doesn't, the current meta is exasperating its existence (or, if you don't believe it exists at all, this is a nothing but lunacy).  So let's go over how this works:

The past meta that we just got over was incorrectly referred to as the "assassin meta" - it wasn't so much the assassin meta as it was the "damage" meta.  It was whatever champ could do the most amount of damage the quickest.  Give it a few seconds thought - the same period where assassins were prevalent is also the same period where hypercarries became incredibly prevalent? That doesn't raise an alarm?  How about Kha'Zix demolishing entire teams just because he couldn't be outdamaged and CC was hardly an issue to him?

Point is, this is the meta where the saying "carry harder" was spoken more than any other - because you could carry harder.  It wasn't about what you could do for the team so much as who's carrying your team and whether or not they could outdamage the one carrying the enemy team.  It's the same reason why if you were ahead you would build damage items and if you were behind you'd build tank - because if you were behind you weren't going to outdamage, so you might as well just soak up as much damage for the one on your team that could.  If your entire team was behind, well, guess you were shit out of luck - unless you hit a power spike or the enemies played flat out stupidly, you weren't about to come back.

And that's how it was - a period focusing on individual play and power limits.  If Akali got fed, that bitch was going to haul her team to victory like Jesus carrying the cross, and if Kha'Zix got fed it was a nuclear wasteland because he nuked entire teams.  And you could viably "carry harder" in this meta, you could - if you went a champ that focused on sheer carrying potential, you could drag your team kicking and screaming from the brink of defeat.

But that's not the case anymore.  Welcome to the "tank" meta as we're calling it - again, a misnomer.  I've seen tanky teams get absolutely annihilated by teams packing no bulk at all, and it's because of the comp.  It's not a "tank" meta, it's a "team" meta.  Brought about by a myriad of new items, your team composition is now far more important than before, which puts the emphasis on teamplay.  This is good - and it's bad.

We have a good side where your team is never really out of the game if you have a good, strong composition - play your cards right and, even if you're not quite up to snuff on items, you can still do your job heavy handedly and come out on top.  It's not "quick, kill Akali before she kills us all, she's all their damage", it's "okay, Galio's going to taunt the shit out of us, so whittle him down before he can reach us so we can quickly kill him and then fight back before the rest of their team beats the ever-loving crap out of us".  It's not "hey Fizz, go dive their backline and kill the bastards and then we'll distract them after you Zhonya's so you can kill the rest of them", it's "okay, we're going to use RG to scatter them, Fizz go pick off a straggler if you can get one, but otherwise I'ma go zone the ADC and I'll probably wind up getting killed but ours can outdamage and-"

You get the picture.  Less focus on who you want to point the finger of god at and more focus on how you're about to play the cards you're dealt to win the fight.

But this is bad for solo-queue.  Because it's solo-queue.  Chances are, if you're finding it to be a breeze to get promoted, somebody else is finding it to be a massive pain in the ass - because if you aren't getting the subpar teammates, then that just means somebody else is.  And there are the subpar ones, oh there are, have no delusions about that.  With how shitty the ranking system is, you shouldn't be surprised if you're getting shafted with some of those leeches.  And with it being the team meta, you can try to carry all you want - but let's break it down for you what the new meta says.

So first of all, you gotta have a proper team composition.  If you're a mix-and-match bunch of ragtag outliers filled with niche roles and almost nothing but that to contribute, you're not about to have a good and easy game unless you absolutely stomp laning phase and end that game fast enough that you never see a meaningful teamfight.

Second of all, your focus is now teamplay - in a perfect world, this means that each player is going to be putting in 1/5 of the work required to achieve victory, and the winning team is the one that collectively did better at that.  Of course, 1/5 is hardly the case - this number is going to vary as generally you will have one player doing the best at all times, but while it used to be that one guy could be doing 4/5 of all the work of the team, this is no longer the case - you're going to be looking at numbers far closer to 1/5.  And that's as it should be in a team game.

So why can't "carry harder" apply anymore?  Well, let's consider: if everybody in the game has the mindset that they must "carry harder", they're all going to be trying to carry.  Because that's the idea, right?  If you can't carry, carry harder.  No exceptions if you want to get to higher levels now!  Everybody has that mindset - but then, that means that not everybody can carry.  You can only really have one person carrying at a time.  How the hell does that work?  You'd have to do all the work for your team every single time you play the game, which begs the question of how the other people in your ELO ever made it to that point.  Surely they couldn't just surf on that many games to there?  Maybe they're all promos - but that's not likely, don't be fucking stupid.

That's just kind of the initial logical dilemma with that frame of thinking - the real problem right now is that it's impossible to truly carry your team on your back - you can't just pool all your money into a single person and have them do everything for the team, it just won't work anymore like it used to.  So consider that your team must all do their parts to win, meaning 1/5 of the work towards victory yadee yadee yada.  If the enemy team's whole number is bigger than yours, then victory they win.  If yours is bigger, then yay you win.  That's what we've set up.

So let's consider that your teammates are behind.  Let's put a number value to this - say, they're all at 900.  You are at 1500.  That's pretty good - you're fed, you're doing work. Right on. You got this.  That's how much you're contributing for your team to victory versus your own team's doing.

The enemy team is at 1200 each with one person at 1300.  Your numbers add up to 5100 - theirs add up to 6100.  You would have to ensure that you - and/or your team - contribute an additional 1000 points to win.  These numbers really don't mean anything, it's more of the logic of the issue - you basically have to almost double your work in order to come even with the enemy team.  And it's not that simple to do anymore.  You can't just say, "Well then I'll go blow up their team while you wait here".  No - somebody has to zone the ADC, somebody has to engage, somebody has to do this somebody has to do that - you can't solo-carry.  It's no longer a thing.  If your top Vlad's got no gold to his name you can't go looking to your Akali mid to make up for his role because it's not about the damage, it's about what a member of your team contributes.  It's why team comps are important - every member contributes a little bit of something to the whole group to make a strong and healthy team.  If one of those members isn't contributing something now, that means you're missing a fundamental point.

What this, as an endpoint, means is this - your ELO and MMR is no longer heavily reliant upon how you as an individual do.  You are now affected far more than ever by your teammates - and in solo-queue, this is a nightmare.  And I would urge Riot to develop a far better way to rank players, because it's no longer a "I got demoted I suppose I'll just carry the three games back into rank" - it's "I got demoted dear god I hope my next three teams work with me well enough to get me back up".  It's not solo-queue - it's "fight with strangers" queue.  It's not just about you - it's also about those four other fucks that all called mid and apparently none of them know how to jungle or ADC.

replies.body:
tl;dr

Basically, if you're in ELO hell you're probably going against people that are much better than you.
Eventually, your MMR will drop so low you'll start to go against people you can actually beat.
Getting good teammates vs bad teammates is a 50/50 chance.
But just because flipping a quarter gives you a 50/50 chance to get heads, you could get heads 10 times in a row. But eventually, it all evens out. Stop writing this elo hell nonsense and go play some rankeds.

Your summary is wrong:

If you're in ELO hell, it's equally likely that it's your mechanics as it is your team mates' mechanics that are holding you back.

He explained his point perfectly. Eventually, as you fall down the ladder, your 1500 + your team's collective 900 will be greater than the enemy's collective score of skill. Until then, what can you do? You can't just run your tip through the whole enemy team. It takes more cohesive team work than just running through 5 random people like a porn star in a frat house, so carrying your team is harder.

Not impossible to be way more significant than the rest of your team, but your team can't be blatantly idiotic either.
ELO Hell is when you aren't good enough to solo-carry your team but aren't facing good enough opponents to improve at any respectable rate.

I think people think ELO hell exists when it doesn't, what does exist is delayed progression. You gotta play around 400 games to be at your "true" elo where you probably won't go up or down much at that point. This is however, if everything works as it should, but obviously some things don't. A couple things that can fuck you up are...
1: Smurfs...
2: Elorift ELO boosters
3: Friend ELO boosters
4: Luck, and this actually will change per person, taking away some games or tacking on some games.

But in  the end, play enough games, you will get to your real ELO.

The problem is finding the time to play like 600 games a season.

You only really experience ELO hell if you go on a long losing streak. Your MMR becomes so bad at that point that it take you MONTHS to get it back up. You will get just a few points for wins but lose lots of points for any loss. 

The people who say it doesn't exist have never experienced how bad it gets.

That is not Elo hell, you have simply falling to a point where your skill level matches your opponents and if you wish to return to your previous ranking you will need to go on a similar win streak that is in proportion to the lose streak you put yourself in.  That's like saying a chess player that was previously 1600 ELO but suddenly dropped 1200 after losing success matches to worse and worse people and ended up at 1200 doesn't belong there, when in fact they do until they prove otherwise...you have made the mistake of losing successively to people ranked below you and so you have proven you didn't belong where you were.
Chess is a 1v1 game. Bad analogy.
No it still fits, one team vs another. Elo measures the impact on your ability to make your team win. It is completely valid. There is only one outcome win or lose sooo....ya it still can be applied.

no it doesnt fit. which was his point that you only refuted to validate your own statement,

My top decided to troll and run bottom lane, forcing our support our team to try and figure out who was playing top while our tower was getting wrecked. he never team fought or complied with anything we asked. we lost.

In my last 10 games i spent all of my time marveling at sheer stupidity of allies who
1. couldnt dodge simple skill shots
2. couldnt understand enemy champion mechanics well enough to keep from dying (tryndmere doesnt die for 5 seconds during his Ult. shocker)
3. didnt understand the proper application of warding and those responsible (hint, it more than just the support)
4. couldnt play the game responsibly enough to provide their 1/5 towards winning and simply decided "fuck these guys cuz reasons"

I'm not saying i deserve Challenger. hell. I wouldn't even say i deserve GOLD for god sakes. but this Bullshit bronze 3 im in where every game i play cant seem to let me play without a disconnect or some jackass who can't dodge a nid spear or shut up and play says yes. 

There is an ELO Hell. Yes you can carry yourself out of it , and i could, but yes. Sometimes you just dont fucking deserve it like you say people do and anyone who says otherwise just wants to be able to inflate themselves with the capacity to say "I did it so just shut up and do it too."

the belief that the bad only play with the bad are bad themselves loves to completely overlook the fact that a person playing in the rift is only 1/5th of their team and that sometimes it just isn't god damn fair to have to put up with the 4 other guys often dragging you down.

No it doesn't. In chess, you're in control of everything. In LoL, you're in control of only 1/5 of the total man power. In a 1v1 game, everything rides on you. If you lose, you suck. In a team game, however, that isn't the case. If you lose, you COULD be bad, but it also could be because that guy's bad, or maybe she's bad, or maybe no one is but that guy in the corner mistimed something.

Bad analogy.

The same applies to the other team....if that was truly the case no one would be able to consistently climb to the higher ranks and yet time an time again if you place a diamond streamer in bronze they stomp right on back to where they belong. Just because there are 4 factors in your team that apply a bit of randomness does not invalidate the system. It just means you need to play enough games (100+) for the law of large numbers to kick in.

This is due to 1 of 2 reasons:

1) You're so much damn better than the other team that your arbitrary number of skill outdoes even 3-4 of their team mates.

2) You were fortunate enough to have a competent team that, even if you weren't the main star of the team, you could still move up anyway.

Don't compare games where you have 100% control to games where you have 20%. It doesn't add up.

The thing is....as has been stated many many times before....in the long run after a 100 games it does. You full well have control of 20% of the game every single game. The enemy then has a full 20% higher chance to fail every single game because every single one of them has a chance to be unskilled, troll noob or whatever. This is why if you can simply keep a 50% Winrate which isn't difficult you will rise and any thing higher will shoot you up the ranks. Seriosuly all these people complaining about Elo hell have sub 50% winrates and expect to climb.  This is a team game and I'm not sayin Elo is best way to measure your individual skill, but it does measure something which I think is important. Atleast in solo que, it Is an accurate indicator of how well you can influence your team and win games...that's all there is too it....those 4 other people are just noise that statistical weigh in your favor because the enemy has 20% more noise. 

> Tldr: get Gud scrub lord ...you can't climb it's because you aren't improving yourself

Thing is, IT STILL DOESN'T add up. It's entirely possible to be in a situation where you're in generally better than your laning opponents, but not better than the enemy team enough to constantly stomp all over them regardless (or nearly regardless) of what your allies, stupid or genius or something in the middle. You can always be caught in a gray area where your still dependent on your allies not being bad, but at the same time your still better than the laning opponents your immediately faced with in most situations. Saying it's cold cut and binary like this is being ignorant. I acknowledge that you'll eventually climb if your THAT good in comparison, but getting stuck in limbo until you can catch a break with competent team members is the elo hell being referenced here.

It's a team game. It's not supposed to reflect individual skill alone like checkers or chess or Smash Bros. Chess is NEVER gonna be a good comparison to a team game.

After that point it is all on strategy  and how you are able to work and cordinate with others. I am proof positive of this. I have been playin since season one were I was bronze. I experienced this "Elo hell" since last season 3. But I improved my play and attitude and am now steadily climbing to diamond (plat 2) now. The truth is all you Elo Hellers are in denial and just looking for something besides yourself to blame....don't look for excuses look to improve yourself instead and you will escape your so called hell.

There's more to carrying than just getting fed out of your mind as {{champion:121}} (although I did just see someone do this, 20 stacks at 15 minutes and what followed was disgusting). You can carry by making the game so easy for your team that a dead gopher lying on a keyboard could ride your back to victory, or you could just make the game damn near impossible for the enemy team. You play your tank perfectly and you're a massive pain for the enemy team because they probably aren't going to be winning teamfights while you peel everyone and soak damage and the enemy tank is just autoing a carry, accomplishing sweet fuck-all while you zone their backup.

If you want to call something Elo Hell, it's what happens when you play without a duo during the summertime. Especially in division 5 of anything. Every game is gonna be more or less settled by some stupid thing that would probably make a good story. I'll list a few:
-kata gets 20 stacks and then trolls for the rest of the game, ending up with like 3 stacks and no nexus
-zed only wants to split, zac doesn't understand not to engage 4v5s over and over
-cait that doesn't poke, doesn't follow engages, and facetanks the whole enemy team in teamfights
-draven/thresh go 0/8 against vayne/janna
Some of those were free wins for me, some of them were free losses. This happens in bronze silver and diamond, only real escape from it is to wisely choose when you play, and duo.
